forum.name: Review and Select a Formative Assessment Lesson
forum.intro:
In this activity, you will review and discuss lessons from the Mathematics Assessment Project website. (Optional reading: A Brief Guide for Teachers and Administrators, which explains the work behind these units and the intent of their design).

First, go to the Index of Classroom Challenges and use the menu on the left side of the website to access lessons from the Algebra and Functions strand. (Click the arrow next to this strand to view the lesson links. You may choose any grade level by clicking on 6, 7, 8, or High School in this menu.)

Take about 15 minutes to explore these lesson units and get familiar with a few of them.

Note that when you click on a lesson and scroll down to “Lesson Type” on the overview page, you can see it categorized as either Problem Solving (P) or Concept Development (C). More detailed information is provided in the optional reading above; however, the main emphasis of each is:

  • “Concept development lessons focus on assessing and developing students’ understanding of significant mathematical concepts, the interpretations that students have of the concepts and the connections between the concepts and their other knowledge.” (p. 3)
  • “Problem solving lessons are designed to assess, then develop, students’ capacity to apply their mathematical thinking flexibly to non-routine, unstructured problems, within math and from the real world.” (p. 4)

Discussion

  1. Select a lesson from the Algebra and Functions strand that you think you would use with your learners, and share it in the discussion forum below. Click ADD DISCUSSION TOPIC to add a post to the forum. Put the title of the lesson unit in the Subject, give a brief overview of the lesson, and explain why you selected it.
  2. Select a lesson recommended by someone else in the forum and investigate it on the Mathematics Assessment Project website. (The high-level overviews of lessons from other participants can be a resource for you.)
  3. Return to the forum and respond to the participant. (Click “Discuss this topic” on an individual post, then click “Reply” to respond to that post.) Possible sentence frames for your reply:
    • I took a look at the lesson you shared and think . . .
    • This lesson would be challenging for me to use because . . .
